snippet: Between $1.2 billion and $1.6 billion in Iraqi funds were stolen after the American invasion and moved to rural Lebanon, a former United States investigator said for the first time, but the trail ended there.
abstract: Former United States investigator Stuart W Bowen Jr admits for the first time that between $1.2 billion and $1.6 billion in Iraqi funds were stolen after the American invasion and moved to rural Lebanon, but says ultimate fate of money remains unknown; Bowen expresses frustration that Bush administration and Obama Administration did not pursue loss of funds any further.

byline.contributor: This article is adapted from “Pay Any Price: Greed, Power and Endless War” by James Risen, to be published Tuesday by Houghton Mifflin Harcourt.

lead_paragraph: Between $1.2 billion and $1.6 billion in Iraqi funds were stolen after the American invasion and moved to rural Lebanon, a former United States investigator said for the first time, but the trail ended there.

headline.main: Investigation Into Missing Iraqi Cash Ended in Lebanon Bunker
headline.print_headline: Investigation Into Missing Iraqi Cash Ended in Lebanon Bunker
